column1: East Palo Alto (abbreviated E.P.A.) is a city in San Mateo County
column2: California
column3: United States. As of the 2010 census
column4: the population of East Palo Alto was 28
column5: 155. It is situated on the San Francisco Peninsula
column6: roughly halfway between the cities of San Francisco and San Jose. To the north and east is the San Francisco Bay
column7: to the west is the city of Menlo Park
column8: and to the south the city of Palo Alto. Despite being called "East" Palo Alto
column9: the city is directly north of Palo Alto. While often incorrectly assumed to be part of the city of Palo Alto
column10: East Palo Alto has always been a separate entity since its founding as an unincorporated community until its incorporation in July 1983. It is also in San Mateo County
column11: while Palo Alto is in Santa Clara County. The two cities are separated only by San Francisquito Creek and
column13: the Bayshore Freeway (the vast majority of East Palo Alto is northeast of the freeway
column14: while all of the residential part of Palo Alto is southwest of the freeway). The revitalization projects in 2000
column15: and high income high-tech professionals moving into new developments
column16: including employees from Google and Facebook
column17: have begun to eliminate the cultural and economic differences between the two cities. East Palo Alto and Palo Alto share both telephone area codes and postal ZIP codes.

column2: 43% of East Palo Alto's residents were African Americans
column3: which was the result of redlining practices and racial deed restrictions in Palo Alto. Latinos now constitute about 65% of the total population
column4: while the proportion of African Americans has decreased to about 15%. A small minority of Pacific Islanders also reside in East Palo Alto
column6: Samoan and Fijian origin.. East Palo Alto has the largest concentration of Pacific Islanders of any American city or town outside Hawaii..

column1: The prosperity that benefited the Silicon Valley during the dot-com boom of the late 1990s largely bypassed East Palo Alto. The Ravenswood City School District
column2: which serves East Palo Alto and part of adjoining Menlo Park
column3: has struggled with low academic performance. Eventually
column4: however
column5: the Peninsula's shortage of land and soaring property prices meant that even East Palo Alto became an option for urban regeneration. Until recently
column6: gentrification has been rare in East Palo Alto.

column1: East Palo Alto also includes a small piece of land across the Bayshore Freeway (US 101) from the shopping center
column2: a roughly triangular area between US 101 and San Francisquito Creek
column3: formerly the site of a two-block-long retail business district known as Whiskey Gulch. The name dates back to the time when Stanford University
column4: on the other side of Palo Alto to the west
column5: was dry and prohibited alcohol sales within a radius of one-mile (1.6 km) from the campus. Whiskey Gulch
column6: which was just outside these limits
column7: became home to a number of liquor stores
column9: and music venues. Long after the university had relaxed its prohibition rules
column10: the neighborhood still retained this character until 2000
column11: when the city tore down Whiskey Gulch and replaced it with the University Circle office complex. A 200-room Four Seasons hotel opened in University Circle in 2006.

column1: The Ohlone tribe of Native Americans inhabited this area at least by 1500 to 1000 BC. One tumulus was discovered in 1951 during development of the University Village subdivision near today's Costaño School. After a year-long excavation of 60 graves and 3
column2: 000 artifacts
column3: researchers concluded Native Americans had utilized the area as a cemetery and camp
column4: rather than as a permanent settlement. In later years another mound was found near Willow Road and the railroad right-of-way.

column2: the area which was to become East Palo Alto went through many changes. In 1849
column3: Isaiah Woods attempted to make the area around what is now Cooley's Landing in the northeast of the current city a major shipping town and named the area Ravenswood. In 1868
column4: after Woods' investments failed he sold the wharf to Lester Cooley
column5: who built a brick factory. When the brick factory closed down
column6: it reverted to a farming community.

column1: With the outbreak of World War I
column2: the north side of East Palo Alto became a military training ground
column3: of which only the Veteran's Administration Hospital in Menlo Park still exists. In the 1940s
column4: East Palo Alto was a farming community with many Japanese residents. During the war
column7: and did not return after the war. In the 1950s the farms were built over with cheap housing and many African-American families moved in. During the civil rights movement of the 1960s there was a renewed interest in African history
column8: one expression of which was a fad for Swahili. In 1968 the area was almost renamed Nairobi
column9: after the center of the Swahili-speaking area
column10: to reflect the population's African roots. Critics of the change pointed out that Nairobi was the capital of Kenya
column12: and had little to do with the cultural roots of most black Americans. In the end

column1: Historically East Palo Alto had relatively little shopping and business compared to surrounding areas
column2: and most of it constituted an unincorporated "island" within San Mateo County
column3: depending on county government for services and on the San Mateo County Sheriff for police protection and ineligible for many revenue benefits requiring city status. After several years of pro-incorporation campaigning by local community groups
column4: a 1982 ballot measure that was stopped by a lawsuit
column5: and a subsequent election the next year
column6: East Palo Alto became a city on July 1
column8: with Barbara A. Mouton as its first Mayor. However
column9: because of subsequent legal challenges to the last ballot measure
column10: it was not until 1987 that the city was officially recognized as such. The legal challenges were led by former U.S. Congress member Pete McCloskey
column11: who represented one of the real-estate brokers whose original blockbusting campaign had turned EPA into a mostly black town. The final tally was 1
column14: a margin of 13 votes and a majority of 50.2%.Significant gentrification occurred in East Palo Alto from around 2000
column15: with the construction of a large shopping center named Ravenswood 101—including a Home Depot
column17: and an IKEA store—and several upscale housing communities intended for high-earning Silicon Valley workers. This development faced opposition from some residents
column18: who charged that it priced locals out of one of the region's only affordable communities while providing only low-paying retail jobs and consuming disproportionate land area (2.2 square miles). Supporters pointed to an increased tax base.

column1: East Palo Alto is located in San Mateo County. Despite its name
column2: it lies almost entirely north
column3: and not east
column4: of Palo Alto. (This may be explained by how directions on the Peninsula are traditionally defined by having Caltrain as north–south. Caltrain runs northwest–southeast in Palo Alto
column5: so "east" would mean northeast. In addition
column6: downtown Palo Alto is in the northwest corner of the city
column7: so East Palo Alto is indeed northeast of downtown Palo Alto.)It is bordered on the west by Menlo Park
column8: to the south by Palo Alto
column9: and to the east by the San Francisco Bay. The San Francisquito Creek defines its southern edge. To the north are Ravenswood Point and the western end of the Dumbarton Bridge in Menlo Park.

column1: U.S. Route 101 cuts through the southern part of the city
column2: with two on ramps and off ramps in the city (University and Willow). There are frontage roads on either side of the freeway. The Dumbarton Bridge in neighboring Menlo Park connects East Palo Alto to Alameda County
column3: which lies to the east across San Francisco Bay
column4: and carries State Route 84 into East Palo Alto toward U.S. 101.

column1: Public transportation is provided by SamTrans.
The Ravenswood City School District has its headquarters in East Palo Alto.The schools in the city are Costaño School of the Arts
column2: Belle Haven Elementary
column3: Los Robles-Ronald McNair Academy
column4: and Cesar Chavez Ravenswood Middle School.The Sequoia Union High School District operates the zoned high schools in the area. Between 1958 and 1976 East Palo Alto had its own high school
column5: Ravenswood High School. After the school was closed because of low enrollment
column6: the building was demolished in 1995 to make room for the Gateway 101 Shopping Center. Following the closure of Ravenswood High School
column7: East Palo Alto's high school students were bused out of the city to other schools in the region
column8: primarily Carlmont High School in Belmont. Some have called for re-opening Ravenswood High School in a new location in East Palo Alto.In 2014
column9: the Sequoia Union High School District discontinued the practice of busing. Today
column10: East Palo Alto residents are zoned to Menlo-Atherton High School in Atherton. Through the district Open Enrollment process
column11: some residents choose to attend Carlmont
column13: or Sequoia High School in Redwood City. Alternatively
column14: East Palo Alto Academy (opened in 2001 as East Palo Alto High School) and East Palo Alto Phoenix Academy (opened 2006) are charter high schools in East Palo Alto. There is also a private high school
column17: parents of incoming minority children in kindergarten through grade 2 can enter a lottery (if there are more requests than the 135 slots available) to send their children to neighboring school districts under the Tinsley Voluntary Transfer Program.

column1: The local area around the Dumbarton Bridge is an important ecological area
column2: hosting many species of birds
column3: fish and mammals. The California clapper rail is known to be present in the western bridge terminus area.

column1: The bridge is not a significant source of noise affecting East Palo Alto; however
column2: it does cause significant traffic backups at rush hour and the city is also affected by noise from events at the nearby Shoreline Amphitheatre in Mountain View.
